 What?
 
 Naaah,...

 Just like abortion and (at one time) slavery.
 
 One thing that has always puzzled me,... "How is it that enemy combatants and convicted murderous terrorists can come away with more rights and sympathy from the left than a prebirth little human child can?"
 
 (scratching head) emoticon_confused
 
 How is it that a leftist can see more outcries for humanity in a whale, dolphin, spotted owl or field mouse than they do in an actual prebirth human child?
 
 One of the great mysteries of the modern world, I suppose.
Sure...like in countries where its legal to stone a rape victim to death.
Not a very good question. The answer is obviously yes. Just look at slavery in the past...legal and immoral...

Law represents the Ethical concepts of certain historical moment.
 
 When social mind changes, past ethics and past laws are considered stupid.emoticon_smile
Law can also represent the horrible misuse and abuse of power...might doesn't always make right.
It's not always a good idea to legislate morality. Do you really want everything you see as immoral to be illegal?

It's not always a good idea to legislate morality. Do you really want everything you see as immoral to be illegal?

 
 Yet there is arguably a morality component to every law ever to be put on the books. Newsflash, you can't have "right and wrong" decided or "just and un-just determined in the absence of any and all morality; no matter how much you wish it to be so.
Conversely laws also PROTECT behavior some see as immoral (freedom to practice certain religions or to 'read' porn).

Conversely laws also PROTECT behavior some see as immoral (freedom to practice certain religions or to 'read' porn).

 Another vague and misleading statement.
 
 What are you actually saying, CUNx?

I'm saying laws can be good or bad depending on the law makers. I'm all about laws protecting freedom rather than inhibiting it (i.e. protecting a right to chose or to get porn). I'm all about laws constraining the govt. rather than expanding it. A dictator can make laws forcing women to become property of men or laws can ensure everyone's right to vote.

Yet there is arguably a morality component to every law ever to be put on the books. 

 
 Yes, and depending on how you define morality. 
 
 
Newsflash, you can't have "right and wrong" decided ot "just and un-just determined in the absence of any and all morality; no matter how much you wish it to be so.

 
 I'm not asserting that just law can be determined devoid of right or wrong. Just that law should not step every time something is immoral. 
 
 Do you? For example, I deduce from your posts that you perhaps see homosexuality as immoral. For you don't think same gender marriage should be allowed. However, I'll venture to guess -- and you can certainly correct me -- that you don't think homosexuality should be illegal. Even though you think it's immoral.

However, I'll venture to guess -- and you can certainly correct me -- that you don't think homosexuality should be illegal. Even though you think it's immoral.

 
 Be vewy vewy careful and walk softwy... I sense a twap!!emoticon_confused

Do you? For example, I deduce from your posts that you perhaps see homosexuality as immoral. For you don't think same gender marriage should be allowed. However, I'll venture to guess -- and you can certainly correct me -- that you don't think homosexuality should be illegal. Even though you think it's immoral.

 
 Although it isn't really possible to legislate morality in a free society since nobody can tell another how they must think or feel, it is both right and the responsibility of the government to limit the expressions of that which is perceived as unnatural and immoral. To redefine marriage for between 96 and 98% of society for the satisfaction of the unnatural expression which the tiny homosexual community is seeking is both justified and rational, not to mention what the government is empowered to do.

That would be something less than 90%, inasmuch approximately 10% of any given population is probably innately homosexual.
 
 And, I fail to see why homosexual marriages would present a problem to heterosexual marriages unless there are great numbers of homosexuals trapped in heterosexual marriages.

I'm not asserting that just law can be determined devoid of right or wrong. Just that law should not step (in) every time something is immoral. 

 
 Do you? 
 
 Every time? No.
 
 
For example, I deduce from your posts that you perhaps see homosexuality as immoral. For you don't think same gender marriage should be allowed. However, I'll venture to guess -- and you can certainly correct me -- that you don't think homosexuality should be illegal. Even though you think it's immoral.

 
 You may be asking the wrong person here. Because I'm a realist, I don't assign any morality at all on anyone's sexuality. I don't know where you get that I do or don't think gay marriage should be "allowed." In fact, I can direct you to some posts where I say that gay's could still enter into all sorts of marriage like contracts even if the government were to refuse to recognize their unions as "marriages."
 
 I believe that homosexuality is just as gentically influenced as is a person's heterosexuality. I also believe that there is a lot of people somewhere in the middle and that their sexuality also is for the most part "genetic." So, (in my opinion) saying that homosexuality should be illegal is a lot like saying that people who are left handed or born with red hair should be criminalized. It would be idiotic to do that.
 
 Finally, I believe (regarding gay marriage) that the government (U.S.) is charged with promoting the "general welfare" and not with seeing that each and every conceivable "union" be recognized as a legitimate "marriage." Specifically, since human beings are most naturally reproduced heterosexually,... It makes sense to me to recognize that as fact as we consider the "general welfare" application for "marriages." Add to that that our children (in general) are best served to meet the needs of the "general welfare" of our society by having a Male role model and a female role model (still speaking generally here) that "heterosexual marriage" best fits that template. And lastly, because I believe it's easiest to avoid incestual problems of half siblings hooking up with one another,... Bigamy is probably a bad idea too. So, the "marriage" model that best suits the "general welfare" of the nation is, was and always will be a "one man one woman marriage."
 
 Not because making babies is a requirment for marriage,... but because making babies and rearing them to be productive citizens is most suited to the nations "general welfare" using the one man one woman relationship.
 
 Gay's can "marry" all they want,... call it whatever they want,... I personally don't care. But I'll still defend the governments right to define marriage as IT sees fit to meet the "general welfare" needs of the nation,... even if that means treating all the other variations to marriage with indifference.

Gay's can "marry" all they want,... call it whatever they want,... I personally don't care. But I'll still defend the governments right to define marriage as IT sees fit to meet the "general welfare" needs of the nation,... even if that means treating all the other variations to marriage with indifference.

 
 I am fine if government is indifferent to the "variation" of same gender marriage, and for example, therefore allows California gay marriages to continue, unabated.
 
 I do not see how same gender marriage impinges on my general welfare. I do see how same gender marriage is in the interests of families, including same gender partners and children, who are also part of this nation.
 
 Bigamy, which you mentioned, is not a marriage variation, but a form of fraud. Government should not be indifferent to fraud, which does impinge on my general welfare and the welfare of the nation.
 
 My deduction of your possible views, as you also inquired, was gathered from our exchange on the polls thread concerning the California proposition.

And, I fail to see why homosexual marriages would present a problem to heterosexual marriages unless there are great numbers of homosexuals trapped in heterosexual marriages.

 
 That is what no one who wants to ban gay marriages will explain to me...just why it is a 'threat'? I don't see what the BFD is... people should be with the one they love and if one segment of society can benefit from govt. recognized marriage, every segment should have the same opportunity. That's true conservativism... equal opportunity for all.

That is what no one who wants to ban gay marriages will explain to me...just why it is a 'threat'? I don't see what the BFD is... people should be with the one they love and if one segment of society can benefit from govt. recognized marriage, every segment should have the same opportunity. That's true conservativism... equal opportunity for all.

 
 Maybe that's because there doesn't need to be a "threat" to heterosexual marriage in order for the government to (justifiably) recognize one form of marriage over the other,... and to remain indifferent to all the variations.
 
 One man one woman marriage is the template that best fits the "general welfare" concerns for the government. (As generally speaking our society is built upon the one man one woman marriage and family structure) Marriage must be defined by our government (article 1 section 8) for the purposes of making imigration and naturalization laws,... in addition to property rights laws and such regarding divorce, inheritence, etc.
 
 It's simply a matter of "man's law" following "natural law" IN THE GENERAL SENSE.
 
 No matter how much the outcry, gays and gay marriage is not the natural "norm" of society. 
 
 It's hilarious, how those who DENY the very personhood of a pre-birth child demand the rights and recognition of gays to marry,.... and they use a thread about abortion of all places to do it.
 
 I shouldn't say it's hilarious,... But I'm at a loss for a better word.

Chuzlife, I brought up homosexuality, not to engage in a debate about gay marriage -- but because you and I had discussed it on the Poll thread about the California proposition -- and it was an easily accessible example of how any of us -- I would presume -- can think of something they see as immoral, but shouldn't be illegal. So, if people want to argue this issue elsewhere, that's fine with me.
 
 My point was, and still is, yes, something can be immoral and legal. I don't think homosexuality is immoral (and since it's up for discussion, yes, I think gay marriage should be allowed) -- but there are other things that I do think are immoral and I think should still be legal. There are things I think are immoral and are already illegal, and I think they should be legal. (And there are things I think are immoral and are illegal, and I think it should stay that way.)
 
 You have now stated, if I understand, that you don't think homosexuality is immoral (though you do not support gay marriage). However, surely there are things you see as immoral, but think should still be legal? That was my point in raising this, to begin with.

You have now stated, if I understand, that you don't think homosexuality is immoral (though you do not support gay marriage). However, surely there are things you see as immoral, but think should still be legal? That was my point in raising this, to begin with.

 
 Point of note,.. I don't conciously do "morality." I don't care about the moral component of anything political or legal. So to answer your question, NO. I can't think of anything immoral that is currently legal that I would want to be criminalized on that basis (morality). Neither are there any laws that come to mind that I would view as being against something which I think should be permitted because it's "moral."
 
 I do believe in right and wrong. I do believe that there is "good and bad" in the real world. 
 
 I just chose not to intermix my concepts of "morality" with anything legal or political.
 
 Of, course,... in the real world all those paths are destined to intersect from time to time. 
 
 I can't help that.
 
 But what I can do,... and what I wish others would do,... is to recognize those intersections for what they are and not let either "reality" cloud the other. 
 
 Keep the religion and morality out of the politics and the politics out of morality and religion,... even as we observe, recognize and accept that they will occasionally intersect one another.
 
 I hope this (one man's opinion) helps.

Maybe that's because there doesn't need to be a "threat" to heterosexual marriage in order for the government to (justifiably) recognize one form of marriage over the other,... and to remain indifferent to all the variations.

Chuzlife, to be frank, and since the conversation veering off in these various directions, I don't really see your P.O.V. If you thought homosexuality was an immoral choice, then, even though I don't agree, your reasoning would make more sense to me within certain parameters. But you are saying (if I get you) that you recognize same gender sexual orientation as a natural phenomenon like being left-handed or having red hair. So, assuming that a man being attracted to and falling in love with men, is just as normal for him, as it is for a man who is attracted to and falls in love with women (or a woman to a woman, vs women to men), why wouldn't you want to allow those persons to get married like heterosexual couples? The general welfare argument, I don't see at all. In fact, the opposite. (1) There's an entire group of citizens who are participating in "marriage", and raising families, but without the benefits, protections and recognition accorded other citizens. (2) Society wants to reward and encourage commitment and monogamy, and, honesty in relationships, not deception and fraud. Not allowing same gender marriage encourages a homophobic society where people live out their lives in closet and charades. (3) Minimal government is encouraged by allowing same gender marriage, because otherwise, people have to seek out benefits and protections through much more complex means. You get more government, not less. (4) Nothing happens to marriage between a man and a woman. People can still marry as a man and a woman. And, since sexual orientation is natural like right-handed or brown hair and brown eyes, why would same gender marriage affect that whatsoever?

lol, I was just going to say the same thing.
 
 Chuzlife, I will add, too, that you keep mentioning bigamy and incest. Bigamy is a form of fraud (vs polygamy, which is entirely another subject), and incest which is a violation of an existing family relationship (among other things, like criminal codes, as in cases of what amounts to rape).

As to your reasons..
 
 General Welfare... if some people being married is good than having MORE people get married is better.

 
 Is that like "if some alcohol is good for you,... MORE must be better?"
 
 I'm sure some overly simplistic people think so,... but it's not supported by any facts that I've been able to find. Using your logic,.. "marriage for the sake of marriage to increase the numbers would be good for the country and the general welfare of all."
 
 I don't think that would be the case.
 
 
Minimalistic Govt. passing special laws is an INCREASE in govt. That should be obvious.

 
 Exactly,.. that's why I oppose special laws redefining the institution of marriage that has served the general welfare needs of the nation just fine to this point.
 
 
 <snip< To establish an uniform Rule of Naturalization, and uniform Laws on the subject of Bankruptcies throughout the United States; <snip< 
 
 Not much there about certian people getting married but others staying single. And we already covered 'general welfare'.

 
 
In determining the meaning of any Act of Congress, or of any ruling, regulation, or interpretation of the various administrative bureaus and agencies of the United States, the word "marriage" means only a legal union between one man and one woman as husband and wife, and the word "spouse" refers only to a person of the opposite sex who is a husband or a wife. 

 
 As you can see by the link to the U.S. Code (above) lawmakers have to define the terms of things they are making laws about all the time. How can the government make laws regarding marriage without first defining marriage (as they have done so now for over 200 years?)
 
 
 I'm not saying that people get married 'for the benefits'. I'm saying they get benefits when they do get married. The only way people can get certian tax breaks and such is to be married...so that opportunity must be available to all citizens.

Is that like "if some alcohol is good for you,... MORE must be better?"

 
 what a horrid analogy.
 
 
I'm sure some overly simplistic people think so,... but it's not supported by any facts that I've been able to find. Using your logic,.. "marriage for the sake of marriage to increase the numbers would be good for the country and the general welfare of all."

 
 No, I'm using your logic. You said marriage 'tween a man and a woman promotes the general welfare. If marriage between 2 committed people is good...then its good to if gays (who otherwise wouldn't marry anyone) were married too.
 
 I supported it from a 'good for the goose' mentality...I disagree with giving benifits to groups...unless that group includes everyone.
 

 I don't think that would be the case.

 
 You brought up the general welfare thing.
 
 
Exactly,.. that's why I oppose special laws redefining the institution of marriage that has served the general welfare needs of the nation just fine to this point.

 
 Again, the govt. shouldn't bestow special rights and privilages to certain groups at the exclusion of others.
 
 
 
 
 
 
As you can see by the link to the U.S. Code (above) lawmakers have to define the terms of things they are making laws about all the time. How can the government make laws regarding marriage without first defining marriage (as they have done so now for over 200 years?)

 
 Let the states define it...but let it be defined in such a way that the most amount of citizens can enjoy the benefits.
 
 
 
Again with the overly simplistic world view. People who live in Florida pay no incometaxes which is a huge advantage for those who live their,... using your logic, "that opportunity must be available to ALL citizens,.. whether they live in Florida or not."

 
 But there's no law PREVENTING you from moving there to take advantage of the benefit. Go to Fl...gay or not if you wish to take advantage of the boon. I'm not saying we should pass a law FORCING gays to marry...just the opportunity to enjoy the same benefits I (or you) can get by being married.

Chuzlife, to be frank, and since the conversation veering off in these various directions, I don't really see your P.O.V. If you thought homosexuality was an immoral choice, then, even though I don't agree, your reasoning would make more sense to me within certain parameters. But you are saying (if I get you) that you recognize same gender sexual orientation as a natural phenomenon like being left-handed or having red hair. So, assuming that a man being attracted to and falling in love with men, is just as normal for him, as it is for a man who is attracted to and falls in love with women (or a woman to a woman, vs women to men), why wouldn't you want to allow those persons to get married like heterosexual couples? 

 
 Where did I say they couldn't or shouldn't "get married?"
 
 To the contrary, I completely remember making the comment that even in the absense of a government recognition of their marriage,... gays could still "marry" one another, enter into civil union contracts with one another, pledge their un-dying love, etc. Do I need to find and link you to the post?
 
 
 The general welfare argument, I don't see at all. In fact, the opposite. 
 
 (1) There's an entire group of citizens who are participating in "marriage", and raising families, but without the benefits, protections and recognition accorded other citizens. 
 
 (2) Society wants to reward and encourage commitment and monogamy, and, honesty in relationships, not deception and fraud. Not allowing same gender marriage encourages a homophobic society where people live out their lives in closet and charades. 
 
 (3) Minimal government is encouraged by allowing same gender marriage, because otherwise, people have to seek out benefits and protections through much more complex means. You get more government, not less. 
 
 (4) Nothing happens to marriage between a man and a woman. People can still marry as a man and a woman. And, since sexual orientation is natural like right-handed or brown hair and brown eyes, why would same gender marriage affect that whatsoever?

 
 1: Yeah,... same thing goes for "common law" couples,... shacking up with each other, making babies and etc. Or TRIADs,..
 
 2: I don't buy the closet thing,.. I've watched Will and Grace,... they're here, they're ##### and they are so happy to be in everyone's face,... It all comes back to the fact that they can have whatever unions they want,... they are not entitled to government recognition as the government is only charged with promoting the "general welfare" and not with seeing that each and every groups get's equal benefits for their chosen relationships.
 
 3: This is the first time I've seen anyone use the "let's streamline government" line to justify gay marriage demands,... Funny. Hey,.. you know what would streamline the definition even further,... ALL relationships qualify,... no rules at all. Cousins, siblings, pets,... you name it ,..it's all good!
 
 4: It doesn't. (But gay marriage is still not necessary for the maintaining of the "general welfare." Our country will, can and has survived just fine without gay marriages. The same could not be said were the government to stop the recognition of heterosexual marriages for the purposes of establishing immigration laws, property rights, birth rights, lineages, etc.
 
 No matter how much you cry about it,.. It's just not the same.

post_info.post_title: I may be straight, but I'm not narrow.

Chuzlife,
 
 If you are going to quote people, please don't falsify the cut and paste with the wrong handle in your blue space. 
 
 
Where did I say they couldn't or shouldn't "get married?"

 
 Oh puleez. This is semantic games. Moving on ...
 
 I said:
 
 
(1) There's an entire group of citizens who are participating in "marriage", and raising families, but without the benefits, protections and recognition accorded other citizens. 

 
 You said:
 
 
1: Yeah,... same thing goes for "common law" couples,... shacking up with each other, making babies and etc. Or TRIADs,.

 
 Wrong on both counts. First of all, common law couples fall under the same laws as those who get legally married. Gay partners do not attain the same protections afforded by law to those who married under common law. Secondly, polygamy is an entirely different question, ILLEGAL in the United States, for a number of reasons, not the least of which is, that U.S. marriages are based on monogamous relationships between two persons.
 
 I notice you keep holding up artificial examples of relationships that are entirely different, but using the ploy of appealing to people's emotional responses to those other relationships. For example, incest -- which is rape. Bigamy -- which is a form of fraud. And now polygamous households, which is an entirely different subject, just for starters, because of the NUMBER of people involved. These are all -- illegal. All of these examples are not addressing the logic of the issues. You are just making an appeal to prejudice and emotional knee-jerk reaction.
 
 
2: I don't buy the closet thing,.. I've watched Will and Grace,... they're here, they're ##### and they are so happy to be in everyone's face,... 

 
 Then you need to familiarize yourself with the statistics on gay teen suicides, hate crimes against gay persons, among other facts of life.
 
 
It all comes back to the fact that they can have whatever unions they want,... they are not entitled to government recognition as the government is only charged with promoting the "general welfare" and not with seeing that each and every groups get's equal benefits for their chosen relationships.

 
 I tell you what. Let's take away heterosexual's right to legally marry and see how insignificant you find that to your life. After all, in your words, you can still "marry". No one's stopping you.
 
 
3: This is the first time I've seen anyone use the "let's streamline government" line to justify gay marriage demands

 
 That's because you're not familiar with literature citing the number of rights and privileges attached to marriage in the U.S. Your opinion isn't based on factual data or anything well researched.
 
 
Our country will, can and has survived just fine without gay marriages. 

 
 People said the same thing down south about integration.
 
 
It's just not the same.

 
 That's about all your argument is, isn't it. Blind fear and prejudice.
 
 Gay marriage does nothing to hurt heterosexual marriage. You are just superstitiously holding up stalks of garlic.

But, according to you, they are....Well then, I guess the govt. believes killing babies promotes the general welfare. I guess killing babies is an action that the govt. encourages to reward families and by extension, society! Since, it would appear in your reality, everything the govt. does is correct.

 
 If only you would take the time to give my genuinely felt posts the same consideration and weight that you do my sarcastic remarks,... we might get beyond this kind of petty "tit for tat" egotistical tendancy you seem to have.

You say the govt. is supposed to be in the business of getting people to live a certain way...that offends me. The govt. is supposed to keep us safe and make roads...not decide what church we should go to or if we can shop on Sunday.

You say the govt. is supposed to be in the business of getting people to live a certain way...that offends me. The govt. is supposed to keep us safe and make roads...not decide what church we should go to or if we can shop on Sunday.

 
 Now if you could only cite a post where I have claimed the government is supposed to be "in the business" of deciding "what church we should go to or if we can shop on sunday,...." you will be giving this (otherwise baseless) assertion of yours a lot of merit.

In earlier posts you kept on about 'promoting the general welfare' as if this means that the govt. should somehow chose the 'best' way for people to live. What it means is that the govt. should protect our inherent freedoms and allow us the opportunity to live our lives.

In earlier posts you kept on about 'promoting the general welfare' as if this means that the govt. should somehow chose the 'best' way for people to live. What it means is that the govt. should protect our inherent freedoms and allow us the opportunity to live our lives.

 
 
 The government has a legitimate role to play in "promoting the general welfare" in such a way as to "protect our inherent freedoms and to allow us the opportunity to live our lives."
 
 Yes!
 
 And to do that, the government must use discretion as to what is and what is not necessary in keeping with the "general welfare" benifits of the nation; AND to reward those things that do benefit the nation,... even to the exclusion of other things that may or may not.
 
 Indifference is not discrimination.

post_info.post_title: The government has a legitimate role to play

I would prefer 'indifference' from our govt.
 
 I'd rather the govt. offer NO 'benefit' than only offer one to a certain group (i.e. a tax credit for being Chinese)
 
 I'd rather the govt. protect the borders, not 'marriage' (marriage will be fine by itself)
 
 You want to bring in the govt. on this...next the other side will have it "promoting" the general welfare of other 'protected' classes and before you know it, you've got an even MORE intrusive govt. than we already have.

Do you? 
 
 I believe that homosexuality is just as gentically influenced as is a person's heterosexuality. I also believe that there is a lot of people somewhere in the middle and that their sexuality also is for the most part "genetic." So, (in my opinion) saying that homosexuality should be illegal is a lot like saying that people who are left handed or born with red hair should be criminalized. It would be idiotic to do that.
 
 
 
 
 Anthony321
 Yes it would.
 
 
 
 Chuz Life
 Not because making babies is a requirment for marriage,... but because making babies and rearing them to be productive citizens is most suited to the nations "general welfare" using the one man one woman relationship.
 Gay's can "marry" all they want,... call it whatever they want,... I personally don't care. But I'll still defend the governments right to define marriage as IT sees fit to meet the "general welfare" needs of the nation,... even if that means treating all the other variations to marriage with indifference.

What is about them that makes you feel that they should not be able to be married? What is about red headed and/or left handed people that makes you feel they should be able to marry?
 Anything that makes it okay to treat law abiding, tax paying, hard working citizens of a free nation, with indifference is not okay! Two consenting adults is not a variation on marriage.

(Article 8, section 1) Nothing more.

 Apples and oranges as they say.
